content:
Hey I wouldn't mind to help on the Zeroize stuff. But looks really stale in `rand` the inclusion of `rand-chacha`.

It might be easier to implement drop-in-place directly for the structs that require it. Or make a wrapper and impl zeroize for it directly.
WDYT?

author: kevaundray
content:
Hey üëã, I‚Äôd say whichever one leads to better readability, a wrapper is usually needed if a struct is used multiple times and you need to zeroize in multiple locations; having it automatically called when the struct is dropped will ensure you don‚Äôt forget.

Note Zeroize is not guaranteed to work since the compiler doesn‚Äôt need to listen to whatever you say (as long as the program is correct), and could copy your secret in memory before you clean it up, so it‚Äôs more of a best effort

author: bridge-bot
content:
<Marcin> Hey @kevaundray @CarlBeek  ,
Regarding load-testing, I won't have time to do that directly. However, please take a look at our integration tests. I have written a mock authentication server, so you can test with it: https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/blob/master/tests/common/mock_auth_service.rs ‚Äì with very little work (just write the main function) you can run it in a separate process. Moreover, I have a rather rich library of "bots" to interact with a running instance, here https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/blob/master/tests/common/participants.rs. In general, I believe you should be able to turn the integration testing framework I have created into a load testing framework with minimal effort code-wise. The tricky bit will be getting a predictable run env for these.

author: bridge-bot
content: <Marcin> Here's an example of such a test: https://github.com/ethereum/kzg-ceremony-sequencer/blob/master/tests/integration_test.rs#L639 ‚Äì spawns the app, runs 10 bots against it, restarts the app, runs another 10 bots, verifies that the state is consistent. It's only shortcoming is that all servers (app, mock auth) and the bots are in the same process. If you split it into separate processes (should be easy, I was careful to _only_ use the public app options in tests, so there's no wonky overrides, it's all stuff you can do to a separate instance) and bump the numbers to reflect real ceremony sizes and 100x the number of participants, you have a load test ready.
